29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. And once again
it is shouty man in a field. Coming up we

35.text:
are on a munty mission. Roy Lupton has got
a nice buck lined up. But with captain camo

41.text: behind the camera could it all end in tears.

44.text: That will come out in the edit.

47.text:
We have our regulars, top gun dog training
tips from Skinners, News Stump and Hunting

54.text:
YouTube. First, for the first time in 2013
we are actually on the pigeons and we are

60.text:
with Andy Crow talking knock down power in
the first of our new series Crow How.

83.text:
It's the first pigeon shooting outing of 2013
- it's not through lack of trying but the

88.text:
weather and the seasons being all over the
place has meant that the birds and the Crow

94.text:
have been difficult to get in the same place
at the same time. Finally it's starting to

99.text:
happen, especially in this corner of the farm
where the birds are flitting between winter

103.text: rape, spring peas, and buds off the trees.

107.text:
What a lot of the pigeons are doing at the
moment is they are still feeding on buds which

110.text:
they should be finished on now. From now onwards
we should be hopefully picking up some good

115.text:
easy day's pigeon shooting. But it is not
going to happen for a while because they are

119.text:
going to be on these buds and as soon as you
start shooting they are going to go away and

122.text:
sit in the ash trees, on the oak on the flowering,
on the beeches and that and they are going

128.text:
The winter rape at this end of the field has
struggled in the bad weather, and the whole

136.text:
crop is behind, which means the plants are
small enough for the pigeons to land for a

140.text:
munch. In a normal year, this field would
be a vibrant yellow with the plants too high

145.text:
for the birds to drop in to. Andy knows where
he wants to be - but that isn't always possible.

151.text:
I have got a field of spring peas next door.
They have started on those a bit. So it is

158.text:
really a bit of a draw to this corner. The
place I want to shoot is a bit further down

163.text:
the hedge, but I don't know if David can show
you. We have got a telegraph pole and some

168.text:
wires going across. So we can't shoot where
I really want to shoot. So we are going to

173.text:
have to do second best go just here somewhere.
It looks like the wires are close to us, but

178.text:
they are not they are 80 yards further down
the field. So we are just going to hope that

183.text:
we can draw the pigeons up the field to where
we want them which is here.

187.text:
Andy has some new kit on test. A1 Decoys,
Lincoln shotguns, Gamebore cartridges and

194.text:
Jack Pyke clothing have asked Crow to use
and abuse their products and see if they have

202.text:
The Lincoln was fresh out of the box yesterday
and old Crow has done all right with it so

208.text:
The old Lincoln doesn't seem to be doing too
bad. It is making me look good. I have had

213.text:
four shots, four kills so I am happy. Oh no
sorry five shots, five kills so I am happy.

217.text:
It is going to take a bit of getting used
to. I am used to the safety catch being at

225.text:
the back of the trigger. On this one the safety
catch is on the top. Yes, apart from that

231.text:
it is a good old thing and the gamebore, clear
pigeons seem to be performing well as well.

236.text:
Andy has always emphasised the importance
of good cartridges for pigeon shooting, for

244.text:
To try and explain a bit about what Crow wants
from a cartridge we need some visual aids

250.text:
... talking a bit about knock down performance
of cartridges and it is a difficult thing

257.text:
for people to grasp. It is a bit subjective
for some people and they don't quite know

261.text:
what it means, but they know what the results
are.

266.text:
So, we have brought some handy visual aids
along to try and explain this a little bit.

271.text:
So can you tell us what the key elements of
knock down power are.

275.text: Dom it is speed, size and weight of the shot.

279.text:
So you can have two projectiles which are
fundamentally the same size, but one of them

285.text:
can weigh more than the other. Cricket ball,
similar size to a tennis ball, but weighs

288.text:
a lot more. So that is going to have more
energy and it is going to deliver more knock

297.text:
down performance than that. So lead shot heavier
than steel shot.

298.text:
Lead is always going to give more knock down
than steel shot.

301.text: Plus the lead performs as well.

303.text:
Basically what that means is it is not passing
through the bird all the energy it imparts

308.text:
is within the bird. The other thing of course
is the speed. So for example if I was to chuck

313.text:
this tennis ball at your face very gently
it would annoy you.

317.text:
If I were to chuck the tennis ball at your
head very hard it would probably result in

326.text:
So we are going to demonstrate that with our
handy dummy because Andy wasn't brave enough

329.text:
to stand here and let me throw tennis balls
at him even though he has seen me shoot and

333.text: he is pretty sure I will miss.

335.text:
In slow motion, we see the jacket buckle to
a greater degree as the ball gets heavier.

342.text:
Another thing that Crow wants to mention is
density or tightness of the pattern. Dom doesn't

346.text:
have 15 cricket balls to throw but Andy likes
his shot to stick together as there's more

347.text:
chance of killing the bird stone dead. As
this footage shows, the lead pellets in the

349.text:
Gamebore cartridge need to be fast, heavy,
distort on impact, and keep tight. Andy wants

355.text: plenty of pellets finding the target.

359.text:
Seeing we're talking about Andy's style of
shooting - these reverse shots show his gun

363.text:
is always swinging through the shot. We also
spot that Mr Crow closes one eye just before

369.text:
pulling the trigger. It may not be the way
they teach you at school but it works for

374.text:
Right, back to the pigeon shooting and the
birds are playing hard to get . Andy has a

379.text:
change around and sticks a whirly up with
a couple of A1 Decoys' new Pro Flap models.

384.text:
Crow is not 100 per cent sure he's set them
up properly as they're fresh out of the box

388.text:
but help is at hand because A1 Decoys has
a YouTube site with an instructional vid.

394.text:
The birds come in fits and starts and we are
constantly reminded that the best place would

399.text:
be on the corner near the wires - but that's
life and we are getting some sport. If the

404.text:
birds do keep to the trees Crow claps them
out for a couple of reasons.

408.text:
I just had some pigeons land in a tree up
there to the left. I just clap them out otherwise

412.text:
other birds are going to just decoy straight
into them and if you do have a shot you are

417.text:
scaring them anyway. You are better scaring
them out to get rid of them, to get them moved

421.text:
on really so they don't hear the loud bang
of a shot.

423.text:
The afternoon has flown by and it's a lot
later than we'd imagined. Mrs Crow brings

428.text:
out a lasagne for one and all so it's time
to pack up.

432.text:
We got upper 60s. We got 65, 66 something
like that and a crow and a jay which is quite

439.text:
In the end we pick up 74 woodies. Crow feels
we would have doubled that if we'd been under

444.text:
the wires but that's life - the most important
thing for us is that pigeon is finally back

452.text:
Andy Crow there ably assisted by the beautiful
Dom and if you want to know more about pigeon

458.text:
shooting why not watch one of our slow mo
films explaining lead. They should be appearing

462.text:
in the cherry blossom behind me. Just click
on that to go through to it. One of them even

467.text:
includes David hosing down his father in law.
Speak of the Devil it is David on the Fieldsports

486.text:
The European Union has turned its attention
towards gun crime and is thinking of banning

490.text:
guns across Europe. Luckily this is only at
consultation level so far. There is time for

496.text:
you to have your say. Please follow the shortcode
on the screen to the relevant EU page.

502.text:
A gun has been produced using a 3D-printer.It
is unlikely to threaten the market for Purdeys

508.text:
and Holland & Hollands but which shows that
regulation of firearms may soon be impossible.

514.text:
This is Cody Wilson of Defence Distributed,
who calls himself a free-market anarchist.

519.text:
Instructions for making The Liberator, a plastic
handgun, are available on the internet.

525.text:
Now for any angler worth his or her salt the
Sportfish Reading Show weekend is on this

530.text:
weekend. The 11th and 12th May. With free
parking and entry the organisers call it the

535.text:
best fishing show of the year with first class
facilities, demonstrations from some of the

540.text:
world's finest game anglers, kit, shopping,
bars, hog roasts it is a great day out for

545.text:
anyone into their fishing.Plus we will be
there filming. Go to the Sportfish website

552.text:
He's back. High street cosmetic chain Lush,
which backs the Hunt Saboteurs Association,

559.text:
got together with our friend Brian May to
back a demo outside DEFRA last week. Around

565.text:
a dozen anti-badger cull protestors painted
black and white gathered to sing and dance

570.text:
outside DEFRA's headquarters in central London.
Not quite the �flashmob' that Brian promised.

577.text:
The feral hog problem in the USA has a new
cure. Meet the DeHogiFlier. US Air Force Engineers

584.text:
Cy Brown and his hunting buddy James Palmer
use a radio-controlled plane mounted with

589.text:
a thermal imaging camera for everything from
finding feral pigs to tracking wounded pigs.

594.text:
Cy finds the pigs and James uses night vision
to shoot them.

599.text:
Finally, here is a story that leaves the European
horsemeat scandal in the shade. The Chinese

605.text:
have arrested 63 people for taking rat, fox
and mink meat, dying it and selling it as

611.text:
lamb at farmers' markets in Shanghai. So far
this year, nearly 1,000 people have been arrested

616.text:
across China for selling fake, poisonous or
contaminated meat and more than 1,700 underground

622.text:
butchers and processors have been closed down.
Enjoy your tea.

627.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

639.text:
Thank you David. Now muntjac and David if
not the finest news reader in the world is

645.text:
a very able cameraman so I have to point out
that David did film the first half of this

649.text:
muntjac piece. However, the second half was
filmed by someone who had to reassure us that

657.text:
Now and again, if he's been a good boy, Roy
is allowed to leave Kent. Today we're on an

663.text:
excursion to Hertfordshire - It's freezing,
and this was filmed a few weeks ago, but at

668.text:
least it is dry. He's a guest of William Alldis
who runs a sporting agency for stalkers and

675.text:
falconers. Roy first met him while flying
his goldie.

678.text:
Thank you very much for inviting us down today.
Obviously I came and had a look with you earlier

683.text:
in the season when we were flying the birds
here and we were after a few hares, but we

688.text:
did notice that you have a hell of population
of muntjac on here.

690.text:
Yes, there is a fantastic population of muntjac
here. There has been very little management

694.text:
of the numbers for the past ten years before
I took over the sporting on this estate. So

698.text:
lots of lovely big bucks and also some large
quantity of cull animals as well that we have

706.text: Have you been quite successful since you started.

707.text:
Well we started in January really getting
to grips with the cull animals because up

713.text:
until then we were doing a lot of falconry
work. We have been averaging six to nine a

718.text:
week since the beginning of January and it
has been a relatively easy time getting rid

724.text:
The hope is we're going to get near a nice
buck today. It's all looking promising as

728.text:
we walk through the grounds with a mixture
of open rides, conifer and broadleaf woodland.

734.text:
William describes his stalking as cheap, fun
and within easy reach of London.

739.text:
Once we find a decent vantage point, we stop
to see if anything decides to pop out for

745.text:
Obviously muntjac feed pretty much almost
all day long, but round here they have really

751.text:
taken to laying up in these woods here and
moving out over the grassland just at the

758.text:
last knockings. The amount we see when we
are out lamping foxes it is just staggering.

763.text:
Obviously you can't do anything about them
at that part of the day.

767.text:
It is fantastic territory for them here - absolutely
stuffed.

773.text:
As we watch and wait, we experience four seasons
in one day... and... draw a blank. But a barn

779.text:
owl keeps us entertained as we lie in wait
a little further along.

784.text:
It doesn't matter if you don't see any deer
when you get a sight like that. Watching a

806.text: barn owl come across like that, just gorgeous.

810.text:
Then we spot a buck. The cover means Roy can't
get a clean shot. He tries to call it but

818.text:
With the light and our options dwindling,
Will suggests that Roy takes a cull doe if

823.text:
the opportunity arises. It does, but this
first one won't stand still.

828.text:
It came round and was going along and into
quite a small ... and then went behind this

836.text: little ridge and into the next field.

840.text:
Another crosses from the other direction.
This time Roy knocks her down - food for the

847.text: larder but no trophy for the wall.

849.text:
We couldn't have left that any later that
was right at last knockings. The light is

854.text:
pretty much gone on us. Luckily she fell on
the spot where she was shot so we didn't have

859.text:
to follow her up because if we had to follow
up in this light and this thick cover it would

863.text:
have been an absolute nightmare. So she bowled
straight over and with optics on there that

869.text:
weren't quite as good I very much doubt whether
we would have had the opportunity to get the

873.text:
shot because it was literally light fading,
last five minutes and that is very often when

878.text:
it happens. Very, very exciting stuff I really
do enjoy muntjac stalking.

882.text:
Fast forward a few weeks and the Chuckle Brothers
are both let out of Kent.

886.text:
We are going for round two with the muntjac
and what we have decided to do today because

891.text:
David does seem to be somewhat of a Jonah
when it comes to muntjac is we have ditched

896.text:
that camera man and changed to one of the
stars of Fieldsports Channel who has agreed

901.text:
to come out and film for me today. So if we
spin the camera around and you should see

909.text:
Andy Crow. I am trying to do this so I don't
have a double chin.

913.text:
It doesn't work does it. There you go. Look
at that. Isn't it a bit scary when you look

925.text:
Yes, especially me. It is not often that I
look at myself in a camera like this and I

929.text:
have got my clothes on. That will come out
on the edit.

934.text:
The weather has improved dramatically and
the deer are out to play. We're not retracing

940.text:
our steps but working through the top woods
- Will knows he has three big bucks and Roy

945.text:
has been offered one of them. A younger animal
shows itself and Will suggests he takes it

949.text: as part of the cull plan.

958.text:
It drops on the spot. A doe doesn't seem to
be bothered that a .243 has just gone off

966.text:
Roy still hopes that the big boy may show
himself but he is happy with the second stalk

973.text:
Isn't it a difference when you get weather
like that. Absolutely superb.

975.text:
Considerably better than last time. Not freezing
...

976.text:
You can't blame the deer for the last time.
That was just horrid.

979.text:
Quite frankly I wanted to be at home in front
of the fire.

984.text:
But no, that was superb, thanks again for
having us.

987.text:
I have been really impressed with Mark today
he has got fantastic artistic flair.

990.text:
Yes, and lots more energy rushing around like
a lunatic.

993.text: David just looked like a sad potato.

998.text:
Potato? OK - Mark's on the case. Very smooth
Mr Gilchrist - Well done Mark - you're hired

1014.text:
... but it's probably best if you don't work
with Roy again.

1017.text: It is rolling, just get on with it.

1021.text:
Well we did get the camera back unscathed
and there was some additional footage on it

1026.text:
which we promised we wouldn't use. This is
Mark explaining to Roy's Korean friend Sang

1032.text:
that he didn't mean to be disrespectful when
he touched his knife. Now what Mark doesn't

1038.text:
know is that Sang was brought up in the UK
and is not a merciless ninja triad member

1043.text:
who would have Mark pulled apart limb from
limb gangnam style at the drop of a tassley

1050.text: I am sorry I touched your knife.

1074.text: Sorry I wanted to look at it.

1078.text:
Sorry Mark. Just to say it was Roy who set
the whole thing up not us. Next up Kit Special.

1085.text:
Kit special this week looks at unusual guns
on the GunsDirect.co.uk website - guns you

1090.text:
might not believe that you can buy and sell
in the UK.

1095.text:
Let's start with this .22 Browning Buckmark
long-barrelled pistol for �525. Good for

1100.text:
rats with a backstop, it includes a Barska
hollowgraphic red dot sight, with muzzle break.

1106.text:
Browning has been making Buckmark pistols
for nearly 30 years.

1111.text:
Next up is a Swiss Arms Model 60 ISSF Target
Pistol, also in .22LR, which costs slightly

1117.text:
less at �500. It is a single shot match
pistol with anatomical right handed grip and

1123.text:
a 12in barrel that complies with UK firearms
legislation due to counterbalancers taking

1127.text: the length of the pistol to 24in overall.

1129.text:
Finally, a combination gun: a Finnclassic
512S. It has a standard set of 12-bore over-and-under-barrels,

1137.text:
a 12-bore and triple-two combination barrel
set and a .30-06 barrel set, so good for pheasants,

1143.text:
change barrels for foxing at long and short
distances, change barrels again and it's ideal

1148.text:
anything charging at you from boar to buffalo
too. Price is �2,250.

1152.text:
That is it. Feast your eyes, fish into your
pockets. Thanks for watching. This is Kit

1157.text:
Now let's have a look what the world has got
to say. It is Hallo Charlie.

1165.text: Here is what the world is up to this week.

1169.text:
Hallo Charlie. This is Igor and Sebastian
from Holland and today we do some ... control

1183.text:
on ... geese. I guess the farmer ... he will
be happy.

1188.text:
Hallo Charlie. Bill Pool. Shooting for ... Arizona.
Ready for the next stage of service ... match.

1194.text:
Hallo Charlie. Wessex Bushcraft, Essex UK
again. This week I am trying to get permission

1203.text:
Hallo Charlie. My name is Tony and I am about
to go ratting and I am taking no chances.

1212.text:
Hallo Charlie. Kevin Adam here. I am doing
a bit of salmon fishing tonight and unfortunately

1218.text:
I have come to my favourite pool to find it
basically completed destroyed. This small

1223.text:
pool used to be twice the width probably ten
times the depth. But over the winter the banks

1232.text:
have collapsed, filled it up and no longer
holds anything. Real shame.

1238.text:
Hallo Charlie not shooting today, but fishing.
Not like me to go fishing, but here we are

1242.text:
with a nice ten pound carp. Put this one back
and back to the foxes.

1248.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie film yourself
on your mobile phone just a sentence saying

1252.text:
Hallo Charlie who you are and what you are
up to. Then share it or email it via Youtube,

1258.text:
Facebook, Dropbox, Yousendit, Younameit to
Charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

1262.text:
Now a speedy top tip from the Skinners Petfood
experts. How to improve your gun dog.

1277.text:
If you want your gundog to get anywhere with
retrieving, you have to get them heading off

1281.text:
to the blindside of a wall. It's a matter
of trust, as top gundog trainer Howard Kirby

1288.text:
It is all about encouragement. It is all about
his confidence. What we do when he is quite

1293.text:
young, but be very careful. Don't start your
dog jumping lots too young otherwise you could

1298.text:
damage his bones. What we do is jump them
over the tiniest of jumps. Tiny log piles,

1303.text:
maybe over a bale. We have got a special jump
run with a series of jumps in it to encourage

1308.text:
dogs to go out and jump and jump and we can
raise them progressively like a set of show

1312.text:
jumps. But that is it really. But in the shooting
field the dog may have to jump something as

1317.text:
big as a five bar gate, or a stone wall or
a fence. It is all about his confidence. He

1322.text:
needs to gain experience doing that. And not
only does he need to be able to jump, but

1327.text:
he needs to be able to jump with something
in his mouth so when he has got a big bird

1330.text:
in his mouth, a cock bird or a hen pheasant
it is a lot of weight to carry in his mouth

1334.text:
and he needs to learn to balance. It is quite
awkward when he is in the air with that moving

1338.text: around. So it is a real skill and you

1340.text:
need to do lots of practice to develop the
dog's confidence to do it otherwise he will

1344.text:
one hurt himself, or he will just not jump.
You teach him to jump on command so that they

1349.text:
are safe otherwise dogs can jump, try to avoid
at all costs jumping barbed wire. It is very

1354.text:
dangerous. You will hurt your dog if you jump
barbed wire with your dog sooner or later

1358.text:
Howard runs Mullenscote Gundogs from Lains
Shooting School near Andover in Hampshire.

1363.text:
Visit Mullenscote.co.uk. This series on gundog
training tips is brought to you by Skinners

1367.text:
Petfoods, maker of the Field & Trial range

From dogs to the world of hunting, shooting
and fishing it is Hunting Youtube.

1385.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show

Viewer Alan Corbett sends in Dora's BackCam

to arguably the fastest bird species in the

1399.text:

fairly falls out of the sky on to this duck.

on a small farm pond that attracts thousands

VideosChassePeche has his English setters

We are in the United States with The Pathfinder

to have a mako shark come for a scoff. "It

man compete in various leagues. If you're

a stalk on a permission he has had for a few
